instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.C7125: What is C7125? Capacitor between CHGR_BOOT and CHGR_PHASE important for bootstrapping creation of PPBUS_G3H on 2013-2015 macbook pros.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: I have this board, no corrosion found, had a short on pp3v42, that is fixed now, but now <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 15.6v already changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> no change...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message:
Change again <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR>.
Be sure to have good solders and traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: Changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR>, traces are good, still getting 15.6v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> beeps with L7130?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 66916, member: 682"]
<RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> beeps with L7130?
[/QUOTE]
no it doesn´t

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message:
Did you solder correct <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> in place?
Be sure all solders and traces are good there.
Check all resistors around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

Please, do NOT quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.
There was ONLY ONE question, no need to do that for your reply.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: I´ve checked all traces, all are good, resoldered <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>, now I´m getting 3,6v at pin 1 of f7140 without the fuse...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message:
Post basic voltages for <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>; pins 1, 2, 3, 6, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.
Check R/C networks from pins 5, 7, 8.
Post exact resistance (ohm scale) between pins 17/18 and 27/28.
Keep F7140 removed for the moment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message:
just measured diode mode on pin 1 and 2 of f7140 (red probe ground, black on pins)
PIN 1- .138
PIN 2- .175
Checked big coils and there is one that has the same value that PIN 2 has:  L7630, with red probe on ground .175, with black probe on ground .199
I don´t know what else to do to make <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to come to life, please help!

EDIT: Got the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to work! it was pin 8 on <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> that wasn´t good. Now I have 8.60, but don´t want to put the fuse back yet. Is the L7630 value correct?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: Check resistance between L7630 and pin 2 of F7140.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: resistance between L7630 and pin 2 of F7140 = 0.2 ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message:
As expected, <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> is shorted.
Change it and pray PCH is still alive.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: Changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>, and still measuring .2ohms, checked L7630 to ground on ohm scale I get 230 ohms in diode mode red probe to ground I get .165 is that a short?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message:
Thre short is between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and L7630, not to ground.
Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> and check if that short disappears.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> and checked from L7630 to PIN 2 from F7140 im getting 3 Kohms and going up. Thanks for your patience, I know this is a delicate line and I don´t want to screw it up if it is not screwed yet...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: Be sure to solder good and correctly <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: resoldered <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> and getting 4 kohms from L7630 to PIN 2 F7140, hopefully that is good and I can go ahead and put in the fuse?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message:
Looks good now, try it.
Be aware, shorted <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> could already affected PCH/CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message:
So I put the fuse back, connected it to the PSU and nothing...  <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> shorted again...
Removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> and there is no short to ground on L7630. that is a good thing isn´t it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message:
Check <RESISTOR>R7631</RESISTOR> and R/<CAPACITOR>C7630</CAPACITOR>.
Change <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message:
just to be sure, I removed L7630 and the short is on PIN 2 in diode mode PIN 1 is .248
it´s dead right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: L7630 looks like this on the bottom, better change it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: is there a way of protecting the cpu/pch when testing with the PSU? I´ve had now 2 of the same year and model which ended being PCH. It´s frustrating, because it was off, but I don´t know if maybe something I did kill it... Thanks for your comments...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message:
You didn't have short to ground on L7630 before?
What is the exact ohm value of that short now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: L7630 PIN 1 0.5 ohm, PIN 2 10 Kohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: You said short on pin 2 before...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: sorry I missed that one... so is there anything to do? Hail Mary maybe?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: If short is on pin2/L7630 (as expected), PCH (CPU) has been killed because of shorted <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>; overvoltage coming from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: Ok, to avoid this happening in other motherboards of this model, what can be done?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message:
That should not happen by itself.
You should protect the board against liquid spill and high humidity ambient.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message: I meant, while I am working on them to not kill them when I connect the charger, that could happen because of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS 15V
threads.message:
Before connect charger, ALWAYS check diode mode to ground on all big coils.
You should interpret the readings correctly, to see if there is any short between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (L7130) and a secondary power supply derived from it.
